qas.question: What does the Great Appalachian Valley do?

answers.text: divides the mountain system into two unequal portions

qas.question: What is common among all the mountains in the range?

answers.text: has no axis of dominating altitudes, but in every portion the summits rise to rather uniform heights

qas.question: What is the climate like on the summits?

answers.text: None of the summits reaches the region of perpetual snow.

qas.question: How many portions is the Great Appalachian Valley divided into?
What ocean is to the south east of the mountains?
What are the names of the interior plains?
What divides the mountain range equally?
Which group reaches the region of perpetual snow?

context: The Appalachian belt includes, with the ranges enumerated above, the plateaus sloping southward to <b4_0>the Atlantic Ocean<b4_0/> in New England, and south-eastward to the border of the coastal plain through the central and southern Atlantic states; and on the north-west, the <b5_0>Allegheny and Cumberland<b5_0/> plateaus declining toward the Great Lakes and the interior plains. A remarkable feature of the belt is the longitudinal chain of broad valleys, including <b6_0>The Great Appalachian Valley<b6_0/>, which in the southerly sections <a0_0>divides the mountain system into <b3_0>two<b3_0/> unequal portions<a0_0/>, but in the northernmost lies west of all the ranges possessing typical Appalachian features, and separates them from the <b7_0>Adirondack group<b7_0/>. The mountain system <a1_0>has no axis of dominating altitudes, but in every portion the summits rise to rather uniform heights<a1_0/>, and, especially in the central section, the various ridges and intermontane valleys have the same trend as the system itself. <a2_0>None of the summits reaches the region of perpetual snow.
